title: Krynauw Otto
text:
Krynauw Otto (born 8 October 1971) is a South African former professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player who played as a <a href="lock%20%28rugby%20union%29">lock</a>.
Playing career.
Provincial.
Otto made his provincial debut as a nineteen-year-old, for in 1990. He then moved to , playing for the under-20 side and in 1993, made his debut for the senior side. He was a member of the <a href="Blue%20Bulls">Blue Bulls</a> team that won the <a href="Currie%20Cup">Currie Cup</a> in <a href="1998%20Currie%20Cup">1998</a>.
International.
Otto made his debut for the <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South African national team</a> in the 1995 Rugby World Cup against at <a href="Newlands%20Stadium">Newlands</a> in Cape Town and went on to play 38 tests.
He was part of the <a href="1998%20Tri%20Nations%20Series">1998</a> Springbok team that won the <a href="Tri%20Nations%20%28rugby%20union%29">Tri-Nations</a> and a member of the <a href="1999%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">1999 World Cup</a> squad that finished third in the tournament.
Otto retired at the age of 28 after medical examinations revealed a <a href="subdural%20haematoma">subdural haematoma</a> in the left frontal area of his <a href="brain">brain</a>, incurred during a match against <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> on 8 July 2000.
Accolades.
In 1993, Otto was nominated one of the five most Promising Players of the Year (under-23), along with FP Naude, Ryno Opperman, <a href="Christiaan%20Scholtz">Christiaan Scholtz</a> and <a href="Johan%20Roux">Johan Roux</a>.
